segments.text: This is an interview with Herbert L. Curry, Colonel, United States Marine Corps, by James W. Hodge, Jr., on 29 November 1988 at Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you, sir?
Yes, it is.
Sir, could you start off with your date and place of birth?
Yes, I was born in Colorado City, Texas, 26th of July, 1939.
Sir, could you outline your education?
Yes, I attended Texas A&M from 1957 to 1962.
I graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree.
Later, I attended the Naval Postgraduate School.
It's the dates where
I have a master's of science degree in management.
Sir, how and why did you join the military?
Not much.
I know how, but I'm not sure why.
Other than I was, as a cadet at Texas A&M, I was motivated to fly and go into the Air Force.
I took my flight physical and found that my eyes weren't good enough to fly.
I decided to join the Marine Corps.
That was in September of 1959.

Since there was not a naval ROTC program at Texas A&M, I had to use another route or path to get into the Marine Corps, and I was given a 10-liter flasher course that they had, which was another avenue for
Actually, the only avenue at that time for people in Texas A&M was to join the Marine Corps.
I knew others from OCS.
So, did I tell you why and when?
Yes, sir.
That was pretty much the how.
The how, okay.
I don't know why.
All right, sir.
Could you have a brief sketch of your military career before Vietnam?
Before Vietnam, I attended
the basic school that all officers attend, that all Marine officers attend.
I think the basic school is what makes the Marine Corps unique.
This is a school where all officers attend.
It gives you a basic training at a level above OCS.
It's basic training in all aspects of the Marine Corps, infantry tactics,
from firing artillery weapons and mortars to understanding about dispersing and supply and logistics.
The beauty of the basic school is that when you leave there, everyone has a common background.
You speak the same language and you can converse on any of the subjects.
If you're an infantry officer and you need to talk to a tank officer or an artillery officer, you both share a common background, an educational background.
You're the first people in the Marine Corps, and you can communicate with each other.
It really facilitates getting the mission accomplished.
After attending the basic school, I went to the 3rd Marine Division in Japan, actually Okinawa.

And while I was there, I was a platoon commander in the reconnaissance battalion, and later on I became the executive officer of the company in that same battalion, and finally the S-4, or the logistics officer.
And I would say that the S-4's job, or the logistics officer's job,
It was probably one of the best learning times that I've had in my career.
It was a staff officer's job to call up their captain when I was the first lieutenant.
But I had to deal with so many aspects of running an organization and supporting an organization.
It placed me in a position where I had to learn what made all the parts move.
I would recommend that to anyone.
Command is fun and great, but you need to know how to use your support staff.
I learned what it was like to be a support officer and what I could provide to the line organizations.
From Okinawa, I went to Camp Lejeune, where I became the executive officer of the company that reports logistics command.
It was called Force Troops at that time.
That's where we had all the heavy weapons at the support units to support a Marine division.
At that time, we had a concept that the entire Marine division should be capable, or all elements of the Marine division should be capable of being lifted by a helicopter.
So the tanks, the heavy engineering equipment, the amphibian assault vehicles came out of the division and went into Force Troops.
I was the executive officer of the headquarters company for a year, and then after that I was the aide-de-camp to the commanding general for a year.
That was another good experience, because working at the general officer level, I saw what factors went into making decisions at that level.
We had the Dominican Republic crisis at that time where elements of the 1st Marine Division, of course, groups there in Camp Lejeune went to the Dominican Republic for that crisis.
Of course, we were supporting that as well as sending forces as well.
When my assignment as aide to camp was completed,
I had orders overseas to the Philippines with my family and went to a marine barracks where I was a guard officer for a period of time and then the executive officer in place.
That was in 1964, 1965 and 1966.
We were stationed at Sangley Point, which is on Manila Bay, about 45 minutes' road distance from Manila, and 45 minutes by barge across the bay from Manila.

It was a small naval air station where we flooded support aircraft that were supporting the war effort in Vietnam throughout, as well as the Navy had the commander in his path for the entire Philippines up there.

When I completed that tour in December of 67, I brought my family back to the States and then went to Camp Penland for three weeks of training for guerrilla warfare as well as jungle warfare before going over to Okinawa in January of 1960.
I think I've left anything out that pretty well rounds out what I did prior to going to Vietnam.
All right, sir.
So could you talk about the date and place of tour in Vietnam, sir?
Before doing that, I might mention that on my first assignment after basic school, I went to Vietnam.
I was part of the 3rd Reconnaissance Battalion.
About two weeks after I got to Okinawa, I boarded a ship with my platoon
worked in conjunction with the underwater demolition team of the 7th Fleet at that time.
And we might have spent three months in Vietnam.
In fact, some three months aboard ship working in the coastal areas of Vietnam doing all the hydrographic surveys as well as the land surveys for amphibious assaults.
And that happened from February to May of 1963.
The second time into Vietnam, I started out as the operations officer of the Military Police Battalion for six months, and then I'd ask for a transfer to an infantry organization.
I was able to go up to the 3rd Marine Division, assumed command of India Company, 3rd Battalion, 4th Marine.
What was that question?
Sir, the date and the place of tour.
Okay.
When I was the operations officer of the 3rd Military Police Battalion, we were assigned a combat sector in the Da Nang area.
We were north of the Freedom Hill complex, as it was called, Freedom Hill being north of the Da Nang Air Base and the headquarters area for the 1st Marine Division.
In a valley occupying the same area as an ARVN, that's Republic of the Vietnamese Army Command training base.
I don't remember what that was called.
But they had a small training facility in the same valley that we were located in.
But we were the primary force in that area at that time.

We operated  we were assigned to the southern defense sector around Da Nang, and we were responsible for the combat operations in that area as well as the military police functions in the Da Nang area, more commonly known as the rear area of the combat zone.

Before moving up to the 3rd Division, I have to mention that the 3rd Military Police Battalion was actually a combat organization, more designed along infantry lines than the Army Military Police line.
We did run the brig and the prisoner of war camp.
We took everyone else and made infantry Marines out of them because we were responsible for defending Da Nang.
And as a matter of fact, the North Vietnamese launched a large attack on Da Nang.
They penetrated the 1st Marine Division's, I won't say lines, but their security zone and actually got into the
the western corner of the air base where they met us and one infantry company that was assigned to us in that area.
That was the big battle at the Cambly Bridge.
After that I went up to the 3rd Marine Division.
That was in August or September of 1968.
At that time the division was located, the division headquarters was located in
I'm having a mental lapse because I only spent one night there before going out to my command.
Not in one tree.
I'll pause and then get my map out.
I'll stop that for just a second.
All right, sir.
Unless my locations and dates have me confused, when I flew in, the division headquarters was located at Don Ha, and then whenever I left, it was located at Quang Tri.
That's way less correct.
I'm pretty sure it was.
I spent one night at Don Ha to draw my gear and then fly on out to my company.
And to get there, I had to go through what was called LZ Stud, which was a helicopter base in the western part of the Northern I Corps up near the DMZ where we resupplied
our infantry units, infantry and artillery units, as well as move the passengers in and out.
That later became Vandergrift Combat Base.
I flew into there, couldn't get a helicopter out for a couple of days, and then finally, when the weather was right, got a helicopter that was going out to the unit, and I was able to get out too.
Thank you.
What was the question?
It was the place of tour, your rank.
OK.
I was a captain at that time.
I'd been in the Marine Corps.
I came in the Marine Corps in January of 62, and so this was September of 68.
Believe it or not, I was probably one of the senior captains at that time.
Because any time that a country goes to war, they take the permanent active duty people and they use them to expand the forces.
And when you do that, you need more people at all levels and promotions are accelerated.
I know as I was, when I was at Camp Finland, we were going through the three weeks training.
Although I didn't view myself as a senior captain by old standards, I had two years in grade as a captain at that time.
Some of the other company commanders or captains that were going through the training with me had as few as 22 months in the Marine Corps.
They had made a second lieutenant in 12 months or less, first lieutenant and then captain.
So when it came to an experience level of captains who were running the companies in Vietnam, it was rather short in many cases.
So I was considered one of the senior captains at that time.
By today's standards, though, that's really not the case.
Captains have five, seven or so years of grade before they come up for major.
I made major, well,
Been a captain two years when I got my company.
Maybe two and a half years.
I was a company commander for that period of time.
And then I made major in November of 69.
So that gives you an idea of the accelerated promotions that we had at that time.
All right, sir.
In Vietnam, what job descriptions did you have?
Well, as I said, the first six months, I was the operations officer of the 3rd Military Police Battalion.

I orchestrated and controlled all the operations of that battalion, which included running the prisoner of war camp, the Marine Corps' military brig, the Northern I Corps, as well as the combat security operations.
and that zoning defense, plus the military police actions in the way.
And as a company commander of India Company 3-4, I was responsible for everything.
That was strictly an infantry combat unit.
I was out in the bush trying to locate, fix, and destroy the North Vietnamese that were in Northern I-4.

concerning the military operations how did you and your unit try to fight the war well at that you have to understand the larger picture before you can put in perspective how my unit tried to fight the war we were far enough along in the war at that time where
The Marine Division, or the units of the Marine Division, had the combat edge over the North Vietnamese.
First of all, we got air superiority, which allowed us to fight a war of our choosing.
In other words, the North Vietnamese, because they did not have air superiority or air parity with us,
were not free to move during the daylight.
They'd roll artillery pieces around or rockets because they'd be picked up by aerial observers and taken under fire.
So theirs became a war at night, primarily, as far as movement and getting into position.
Because we enjoyed that air superiority, we had the upper hand on the battlefield.

Because it was a political war as well as a military war, we realized that if we were ever going to get out of there, we being the administration and the commanding generals, is that we would have to work with the Vietnamese forces, train them, and give them the wherewithal so that they could eventually stand up against the North Vietnamese army.
And we were in the process of doing that.
We realized that we couldn't control the entire countryside, in other words, blanket the mass of people.

So we started working out of strategic positions, key points, key terrain points, where we could control that and use an approach, working with the Vietnamese so that they could stand on their own feet and take over.
So ours was a war of movement.
where each company would move roughly every three days.
They would go into a position, patrol, defend there, try to locate and find the enemy and destroy them, and then move on.
We stayed on the move.

We were on the offensive the whole time, which kept him off balance because he couldn't go to a static position and defend there because once we found him, then we could bring in massive combat power, the artillery in the air, and not take him off.

So our job as a company was scouting and patrolling on large-sized unit level, moving around covering large distances, hoping to find the North Vietnamese at which time they would be conferred actual forces on them.
I'd say the worst part, the North Vietnamese were very good soldiers.
They were not risk-takers.
But if they located you and you didn't move, then they would conduct their reconnaissance, develop their plans and reverse them.
And when they would attack, if you had been in that location very long, you knew that you were in serious trouble.
Because they were very confident in their abilities, they had a good game plan, and they were prepared to take you out.
And that's  that type of action as opposed to a meeting engagement where you accidentally run into people or unexpectedly run into an enemy force and you have to fight.
There we were far superior to them because we could call in artillery, we could call in air.
Without  except  well, with very few exceptions, we always came out the victor on those types of occasions.
If you were placed on a hill for a certain length of time and left there by yourself, that's a company now of anywhere from 85 to 180 people depending on the strength at that time.
If it was an attack of his choosing, if you were in for a good battle, it would take a lot of capital.
All right, sir.
What are your training and experiences in combat?
training prior to combat?
MR.
Yes, sir.
Of course, the basic school teaches all the officers the infantry basics, but you can't stop there with the training.
From there, I went on to the 3rd Reconciliations Battalion, which is an infantry organization, although it specializes in reconciliations.
You also have an infantry nation.
your daily role was to train the execution of that machine.
So that was continuous training in anti-tactics.
That was all the way up through first lieutenant.
From there, when I went to force logistics command, that was staff work.
where you learn what it takes to support, and that gives you a different view of operations.
But that in itself is training, not infantry training, but it teaches you what to call for when you need support.
Then when I went to the Philippines, although that was Guard duty, we had a training schedule, and we would go out into the countryside and conduct infantry training.
Here I took great advantage of the

enlisted Marines that I had who had been assigned there after Vietnam to draw their experience and techniques, to teach the others, the Marine parents, what it was like over there, what you could expect or anticipate, and those tricks of the trades necessary to survive in the combat environment.
Sir, so that type of training was your own idea?
That's correct.
All right.
You were in Pendleton three weeks before you went to Vietnam?
Yes.
And what training did you receive there?
There was training there as well.
That was jungle training and survival training.
We had courses that we went through that taught you how to identify mines and booby traps, taught you how to be alert for trip wires or activation devices so that you could avoid those or stop them.
Not only would you avoid them, but everyone else would be able to avoid those tripwires and explosive devices.
We had infantry training, weapons training.
We had conditioning hikes both day and night.
We had a lot of training in nighttime.
It was an intensive period, an intensive three-week period in camp before we boarded aircraft.
Were the instructors there?
The folks that had been in Vietnam?
Yes, without exception.
They were all combat veterans.
And were the experiences you had during the training the same that you actually had in Vietnam when you were fighting?
What was the school, did it adequately prepare you?
I don't think anything adequately prepared you for combat other than combat.
No, it didn't prepare me for combat, nor did it prepare the junior Marines for combat.
That's not being critical of the school.
I'm just saying that nothing can really prepare you for combat.
It's a completely different environment than what you're accustomed to.
For instance, you're out there in the middle of nowhere,
of the Weather Rifle Company with no visible means of support.
I only rode on trucks one time in six months.
Wherever we went, we either had to walk or there was a helicopter.
All food and water had to be sent by helicopter.
When the weather was bad, we would have to send details down to the hills and the mountains, down to the spring bass at the bottom of the mountains and collect water.
We learned that if we didn't eat all of our rations, we should bury them, because we might come back to that location and not be able to have it be resupplied by air.
If that were the case, then we could dig up our old caches and re-stash them.
Battles or firefights are short and intense in most cases.
and no training to prepare you for that.

If you have a meeting engagement, complete chaos breaks loose, and you hope that the training that you had before that, as well as the training that you conducted in the combat zone, mentally prepares you to react without thinking.
And most, in all cases, it did, I guess.
But to give you an example, an ambush is probably the most difficult situation in the ground response.
You're in a killing zone, the enemy is standing waiting for you, and he springs the trap on you, so to speak.
The only way to get out is to fight your way out.
You can't hit the ground, because there's no protective cover there.
They chose the site to have this.
You've got to turn in the directions of the guns that are firing at you, and assault them.
And that's got to be reflex action, because every second that you stay in that killing zone, it's more dangerous.
We can train to do that and condition people to do it.
But until they've actually been fired at in anger, we're not prepared.
Yeah.
In other words, it's a shock the first time it happens.
Yes, the training that goes on beforehand, the peacetime training, the training that goes on just prior to going out into a combat zone, is mental conditioning.
Teach Marines to instantly obey orders.
If someone hollers, ambush right, most of the people would automatically face to the right and start firing.
So, yes, that training was impactful.
Not only is training prior to getting to a combat zone important, you've got to continue training when you get into a combat zone.
You're not engaged in the enemy every day.
You may go three weeks or two months without engaging.
That was because of that type of war.
But that's not uncommon in other wars either.
When you're not engaged, you're out patrolling, you're in your defensive positions, you're firing your support weapons.
That's training as well as actual operations.
But for those people that aren't out conducting the patrol or ambulance, in the daytime, you need to be having classes for those people, practical and proficient.
It's not like standing down to a no-sweat garrison environment back in the States because the threat's always there if you haven't maintained proper security.
But as far as basic things like proper digging of a fighting hole,
clearing fields of fire, proper scouting and patrolling techniques, setting up your fans of fire for your various weapons systems.
That still takes training.

You've got to remember that most of the Marines that went over there came right out of boot camp, and they haven't had the opportunity or did not have the opportunity to be in an infantry organization for a year or two years before they got there and learn all these skills and refine all these skills.
They're just a basic movement together.

So unless you want your unit to fight at its lowest combat denominator, that being the least trained person, you've got to continue with the training program in combat to improve those skills that they receive in boot camp and in the training school.
And that just takes a conscious effort, because there's not a formal training program as we have it in peacetime.
But each company commander needs to work out the program and do those types of things.
All right.
Sir, I need to change the table.
OK.
